contentrichtext.text: {{Taxation in the Ottoman Empire sidebar}} {{Wiktionary|defter}} A '''Defter''' (plural: ''Defterleri'') was a type of tax register in the [[Ottoman Empire]]. The information collected could vary, but tahrir defterleri typically included details of villages, dwellings, household heads (adult males and widows), ethnicity/religion (because these could affect tax liabilities/exemptions), and land use.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cosgel|title=Ottoman Tax Registers (Tahrir Defterleri)|journal=Historical Methods: A Journal of Quantitative and Interdisciplinary History|year=2004|volume=37|issue=2|pages=87–100|url=http://digitalcommons.uconn.edu/econ_wpapers/200247/|accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> The defter-i hakâni was a land registry, also used for tax purposes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Barnes|title=An introduction to religious foundations in the Ottoman Empire|year=1987|publisher=Brill|isbn=978-90-04-08652-4|pages=151}}</ref> These records are useful for historians. Some Ottoman officials responsible for these tax registries were known as [[defterdar]]s. The term is derived from Greek ''diphthera'' διφθέρα meaning book (having pages of goat [[parchment]], used along with papyrus as paper in Ancient Greece) borrowed into [[arabic language|Arabic]] دفتر: ''daftar'' meaning book. The term '[[diphtheria]]' or 'diphtheritis', acute contagious disease caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae (Klebs-Loffler bacillus) has the same origin<ref>[http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/Diphtheritis]</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Government of the Ottoman Empire]] {{Ottoman-stub}}
